title: PKH Conditional Cash Transfer
summary: Indonesia's Program Keluarga Harapan (PKH), launched in 2007, grew to cover 10 million families by 2020. World Bank evaluations found school enrollment gains of up to 9 percentage points and improved maternal health, while digital payment integration modernized delivery to reduce leakage.
content:
## Background

Indonesia, the world's fourth most populous country with over 270 million people, faces persistent challenges of poverty, inequality, and inadequate social services despite sustained economic growth since the 1997 Asian financial crisis. In the mid-2000s, approximately 17% of the population lived below the national poverty line, and many more were clustered just above it, vulnerable to shocks. Child malnutrition rates were alarmingly high, with approximately 37% of children under five stunted (chronically malnourished) as of 2013. School enrollment, while high at the primary level, dropped significantly at the secondary level, particularly for children from poor families.

Indonesia's social protection system had historically relied on subsidized fuel and food prices, which were expensive, poorly targeted, and economically distortionary. A series of fuel price increases in 2005-2006 freed fiscal space and created political momentum for more targeted social assistance programs. The success of conditional cash transfer (CCT) programs in Latin America, particularly Mexico's Progresa/Oportunidades and Brazil's Bolsa Familia, provided a policy model.

The government of President Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono launched the Program Keluarga Harapan (PKH), or Family Hope Program, in 2007 as a pilot conditional cash transfer targeting the poorest households. The program was designed with technical assistance from the World Bank and drew explicitly on international best practices in CCT design.

## The Intervention

PKH provides regular cash payments to poor households conditional on compliance with requirements related to education and health. Education conditions require children aged 6-15 to maintain school enrollment and a minimum 85% attendance rate, and children aged 15-18 who have not completed basic education to enroll. Health conditions require pregnant women to attend prenatal checkups, use trained birth attendants, receive postnatal care, and ensure children under 6 receive scheduled vaccinations, growth monitoring, and vitamin supplementation.

The program was piloted in 2007 in 7 provinces covering 48 districts, initially reaching approximately 387,000 households. Expansion was gradual, reaching 3.5 million families by 2015, then accelerating dramatically under President Joko Widodo to 10 million families by 2020. Transfer amounts were restructured in 2019 to a component-based system, with separate payments for pregnant women, young children, primary school children, secondary school children, elderly members, and disabled members, totaling between Rp 1.89 million and Rp 3.47 million per family annually.

A critical innovation was the shift to digital payments. Initially, transfers were distributed in cash through post offices, a process prone to delays, leakage, and high transaction costs. Progressive digitization moved payments to bank accounts and mobile wallets, with over 96% of beneficiaries receiving payments electronically by 2020. Alatas et al. (2012) conducted influential research on targeting methods, comparing proxy means testing, community-based targeting, and hybrid approaches to identify the most effective mechanisms for identifying the poor.

## Results & Evidence

The World Bank's impact evaluation of the PKH pilot (2011) found significant positive effects on several health and education outcomes. Secondary school enrollment increased by approximately 7-9 percentage points among beneficiary households. Prenatal care visits increased by about 9%, and the share of births attended by trained professionals rose. Child immunization rates and participation in growth monitoring improved measurably.

Sparrow, Suryahadi, and Widyanti (2013) analyzed PKH's targeting performance and found that the program was reasonably well-targeted by international standards, with the majority of benefits reaching the poorest quintiles. The shift to digital payments reduced leakage and administrative costs while improving timeliness. The government's broader push toward a unified social registry (Basis Data Terpadu) improved cross-program coordination and reduced duplication.

Contributions to malnutrition reduction have been harder to attribute definitively. Indonesia's national stunting rate declined from 37.2% in 2013 to 24.4% in 2021, but this reflected multiple simultaneous interventions including water and sanitation improvements, nutrition-specific programs, and general economic development, making it difficult to isolate PKH's specific contribution. Nonetheless, the World Bank and other assessors credited PKH as a significant component of Indonesia's evolving social protection system.

## Challenges & Criticisms

Conditionality compliance monitoring remains a significant operational challenge. With 10 million beneficiary families spread across the world's largest archipelago, verifying that children actually attend school and that mothers actually visit health facilities is logistically demanding. Facilitators (pendamping) assigned to monitor compliance are often overwhelmed by large caseloads, and the quality of monitoring varies substantially across regions.

The adequacy of transfer amounts has been questioned. At Rp 1.89-3.47 million per year ($130-240), the transfers are modest relative to the costs of compliance, particularly in remote areas where accessing health facilities and schools involves significant transportation costs. Graduation and exit strategies remain underdeveloped: the program has limited mechanisms to help families build sustainable livelihoods that would allow them to exit poverty permanently rather than depending on ongoing transfers. The COVID-19 pandemic, which pushed millions back into poverty, tested the program's capacity for rapid expansion and adaptation.

## Key Lessons

- Conditional cash transfers can effectively increase school enrollment and health service utilization among poor households when transfer amounts are meaningful and services are accessible.
- Digital payment infrastructure dramatically improves the efficiency, transparency, and timeliness of cash transfer programs, reducing administrative costs and corruption.
- Targeting methodology matters: combining proxy means testing with community verification can improve accuracy in identifying the poor in diverse contexts.
- Scaling from pilots to national programs requires sustained political commitment, administrative capacity building, and progressive improvements in data systems.
- CCTs address demand-side barriers but must be complemented by supply-side investments in school and health facility quality to achieve human capital development goals.
